pros: The few Pros to being there have been eliminated by the leadership, the board, the university president, and the departmental heads. The cancerous, toxic, political atmosphere of the state government is felt in the chain of command. I state this because it has deteriorated the few Pros left.
cons: Well, cons, “It’s definitely not the Pay!” Even your department heads will finally admit it; however, they make more than you. So, just image how that makes you feel, when you’re being paid, 40K less than them. Career advancement is like the Klingon empire. If you’re willing to throw your fellow employees under the bus, or if you’re 100% company brown noser, and sell everyone else out you might move up. Then again it might not happen for years.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Memphis, TN
pros: great school helped me learn alot
cons: no cons for this employer

pros: You can do homework if there's no work to do. Other staff are nice, and very flexible hours. Supervisors are okay with you putting school first.
cons:
One of the things we need to do is complete at least the first stage of group of quizzes/assignments. Then there are two more stages that you can complete that are optional, but offer a higher pay.
There was supposed to be a packet with a folder, which was needed to submit the assignments--and was needed to DO the assignments.
No one got this.
The quizzes were set up poorly, the questions were bad, and a lot of the quizzes never reported grades, and were duplicates. 

Whoever was in charge of this was really hard to get ahold of. She never answered her phone, she ignored emails, and you had to harass her to get any sort of response. She even ignored my supervisor, who tried to contact her about how none of his workers could complete the first level (which you needed to continue working).
Eventually, most of us got past level one--and some of us bothered her enough to make it to level two.
But that was ridiculous

review_title: It’s an OK Place to Start
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: The biggest pro is obviously free tuition while you're in graduate school. Other pros would be dependent on which faculty and department you work for. Some people are assigned simple jobs that are worthless, as far as work experience is concerned, but get to take it easy, hang out, and do their homework most of their shift. Other people get tougher jobs that look great on a resume. This largely varies.
cons:
On the down side, if you are a straight-A student, your department may give you 4 times the work of the B and C students. This looks good on a resume, but it can quickly turn into far more work than you agreed to. I've had faculty treat me like their full time slave and become rude towards me when I didn't work my butt off for them on my days off. 

I personally would have been been better off getting a "real" job. I don't have the benefit of taking it easy and doing my homework that many students do - and the pay is far too low for me to pay my bills. I'm still glad to have the experience on my resume though - so no regrets.

Again, your mileage may vary.

pros: the working environment is very comfort.
cons: the salary is not as competitive as other universities

pros: Can get homework done while working
cons: Graveyard shifts are sometimes the open shifts to work

pros: Great teachers and resources. Perfect school for commuters. Affordable tuition.
cons: The parking could be improved to accomodate all the students.

review_title: Was okay when I needed a job, but moved on as soon as I was able to.
pros:
- I had some of the best co workers I've ever had.  However, I think our bond was so strong because we had to stick together to withstand the incredibly poor management of our director and other higher ups.
- Working for the state means great benefits.
- Good hours - 37.5 hours, rarely any overtime.
cons:
- People get promotions there because of who they know, not because they are best for the job or most qualified.
- Pay was incredibly embarrassing.  They "prefer" Master's educated applicants for most positions, but certainly don't compensate those people for their education.  
- No movement within.  There is no chance for advancement within that place.  As a general rule in higher ed, you have to be willing to move institutions to make big movement, but there INCREDIBLY low levels of opportunity there.

pros: Get to fly decent airplanes
cons: everything else is not so great

review_title: A good school with an inferiority complex
pros:
Many, very dedicated individuals toil away at MTSU with little in the way of recognition.  Good people.
There are some very good students - not as snotty and entitled as you will find at other types of institutions.  I loved the impact of the Music / Recording Industry track students on the campus culture.  Lots of musicians carrying their instruments around campus and music being played by students in between classes.  Lovely.
cons: This has historically been a commuter campus so there is some baggage there.  not much going on, on-campus after 6pm or on weekends... Students commute as far away as Nashville and really don't have time to connect with the campus other than to check in for class and quickly check out.  Students carry on with full-time jobs which holds back their potential to perform in the classroom.

pros: good health insurance options, vacation and sick leave, atmosphere was wonderful, when I arrived-felt i made a difference, now a cog in a  machine.  I have  many genuinely dedicated coworkers and there are some incredibly gifted professors and amazing students.  Its fun to see students enthusiam and the odds some students face to succeed are amazing.
cons: has lost sense of purpose, "student centered" a shallow version of customer service rather than genuine sense of mentoring, stretching, and building young minds and character.  Also employee morale is very low because the job you hire on for mutates unendingly and then rather than affirming flexibility and willingness to go the extra mile there is an uspoken "20 people want your job" pressure.  To some degree this depends on your department and immediate supervisor but there is an overall malaise.

pros: Flexible schedule, I have been able leave early/ come in late if needed. Small team means there is a family environment. I have also had a lot of autonomy over my work which has helped me be successful in my role
cons: The pay is horrible. It is below even industry standard. They have recognized it, but aren't doing much to support it. They are driving up the requirements to increase the pay, but that means those people are underpaid. There is also a huge discrepancy in pay. People doing the same thing in other divisions are making more. This stems from a lack of support from leadership. Leadership can go against HR to negotiate your pay, but they won't in this division. There is favoritism across the division as well. Some departments see way more support than others. The president has also been in his role way longer than industry standard so no new vision.

pros: Working as an academic tutor for Middle Tennessee State University never seemed over-bearing. It was fairly simple to balance my work schedule with classes and so forth without one sliding to the back-burner.
cons: The only downside to working my position as a tutor was the fact that I was the only one with in-depth knowledge of the engineering design courses, which meant that some days I would be the only tutor receiving students to assist in the engineering office. This wasn't a problem for me, but other tutors expressed some concern regarding the fact that they would hardly have any students to tutor in their respective fields. The only other thing I wish was that I could have started this position sooner instead of my last semester in college.

review_title: Friendly Environment but slow as hell
pros:
people are super friendly and incredibly great at heart and in the face.
there are many passionate students to interact with.
you can find many knowledgable professors on the campus.
peaceful environment
cons:
Everything is so slow,  they work when they feel like working
Managers really do not care about making things better
Some buildings are old and need immediate 
Not many funding opportunities
IT support is the worst ever, lovely people but with no care for the service
not a research university from a professor or a student point of view

pros: I was a student worker in an academic office at MTSU.  The staff was great - really flexible with my class schedule and also helpful when it came time to choose classes for my minor.  I also got the opportunity to get to know my professors much better as I was seeing them 3 - 4 times a week outside of the classroom.
cons: A couple of the professors complained about their students a lot.  It was a little frustrating to hear that much negativity.

review_title: Not a place for doing advanced research
pros: There might be some interesting opportunities to interact with some talented people. The campus is close to Nashville. Mostly problem free town.
cons: This is not a place for doing advanced research. The university does not put emphasis on research as a way to get its profile higher. It is more of a glorified community college. Even though they have a few graduate programs thrown in the mix, those programs receive almost no funding. The research budget is almost non-existent at this university.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: You are able to get teaching experience as a graduate student, which pays for (a majority of) tuition and also provides a small stipend. There is quite a wide variety of students at MTSU, so you are challenged as a young instructor.
cons: The position only requires 20 or so hours per week of work, but the stipend itself does not pay very much. Students will likely have to work another job to cover their expenses on top of classes, research, etc.

pros: No pros except the job itself was enjoyable. I got to take pictures of students and create an online magazine win HTML. However, doing all of that for no pay is illegal and I should have reported it, but I thought they would have made up for the 3 months no pay in time.
cons: He didn't pay me for 3 months because they "didn't have the money." Finally began getting paid afterwards $8.50/hour and they never made up for the 3 months so I ended up quitting. Oppmann begged me to work again and said, "I have money, plenty." This is why people have go on strike in front of the university.

pros: Working as a desk assistant gives students a little income. It does not require mental/physical exertion, which is great while being in school. The job requires that you sit behind the desk, answer the phone, check out keys, and complete a desk log.
cons: The RA's do get first pick of desk hours. They usually choose hours during the day. You cannot leave from behind the desk unless another student worker is behind the desk. So if you are working odd hours (3 am) and no one is there, you can't go to the bathroom. Unless you bring a book or something, you'll be very bored because no electronics are allowed while being clocked in.

review_title: Would go back if the pay was close to in-line with private industry
pros:
This is a relatively low stress environment. When things go wrong they are simply fixed without undue stress.

The people I worked with across the campus were wonderful. I can’t think of even a single person who was less than professional and most went above and beyond.  

The benefits are very good. 

There is a good mix of very modern and older technology to give someone working in IT an interesting day.
cons: The only real con I and offer is that, at least in IT, MTSU was significantly below the Nashville pay norm. Ultimately I left for more money and no other reason.

pros: The people were nice to work with. They had good benefits and they took good care of their people. We worked as a team to get the jobs completed in a timely matter.
cons: Parking trying to find a place to park during school time was difficult. Raises were not given the way they should have been. Some years we received nothing. By the way my last year of employment was in 2007. I was unable to place that in the designated spot.

review_title: Great place to work with amazing people!
job_title: Disability and Access Center in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: I loved the people that I worked with. It was like we were a family. Everyone got along and all shared the same goal- to help others.
cons: The challenges were not with the staff but rather the students. They could often get rude or angry when things did not go their way.

pros: Pays completely for school while in assistantship. You only work 20 hrs week. You get off work for all the holidays the school recognizes. $800 month pay.
cons: Nepotism allowed to occur. Little to no feedback from management. No feedback on work done well or correctly. Little instruction in how to correctly conduct work.

review_title: Different Rules for Federal Work Studies Students
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: MTSU is a quality University, so you are working for great professors who really partner with you to help ensure that your assignment actually advances your career goals. My program director does an excellent job of providing me the most appropriate assignment, and my supervising professor does an excellent job of providing opportunities for me to learn and advance my career skills.
cons: While this is not the university's fault, or even something within their control, due to federal guidelines, FWS (Federal Work Studies) students are not subject to the same rules and pay rate as Graduate Assistants who are funded by the department. They are subject to different contracts, which results in students who are funded by the FWS program earning less than those who are funded by the department, since FWS students are paid on a per hour basis, they may be unable to earn the amount that they were contracted for because of non-service periods preventing them from "clocking" the required number of hours over breaks, while "regular" GTAs are paid a set stipend on a non-salary basis for "up to 20 hrs. a week" and their stipend is not altered during breaks.  Unfortunately, since the students who qualify for FWS funding are those who are most economically disadvantaged, this results in a classist payment system, where those with the most need are payed less than those with less documented need.

review_title: Good and bad - need a good attitude to be successful
pros: laid back environment, office staff are always helpful and supportive
cons: Lots of frustration with across the board low pay among faculty and staff.  Salaries are not close to comparable schools.  Due to this, turnover is high in some departments and is increasing.

pros: Worked with some good people in the athletic department and really appreciated getting my first opportunity in the industry.  The pay was low, but what you would expect for a beginning assistant coach position.
cons: While I was there MTSU was stuck between trying to move from being an irrelevant Mid-Major athletic program to a relevant Mid-Major athletic program.  The recent move to Conference USA may help that, but they had been discussing the potential move when I arrived back in 2006.

pros: MTSU was a great place to earn extra income while finishing my undergraduate degree. I worked in the Agriculture department. They were super flexible with my extracurricular schedules and always had many opportunities to wok extra hours if desired. Also paid above minimum wage.
cons: No cons. Be prepared for physical labor with some of the jobs though. This was not an issue for me, but is something to keep in mind working in that department.

pros: The standard work week is 37.5 hours, so with a position that requires little overtime, the work / life balance is very, very good.
cons: Information Technology is seriously understaffed and underfunded.  The number of positions should be doubled to even approach the number of positions required to support a university of this size.

pros: Some of the greatest benefits include free tuition and hands-on experience with professors. In addition, you get the opportunity to refine your skills for the workplace.
cons: While the benefits outweigh the cons, there is always the chance that you get linked up with a professor you don't really gel with.

pros: Amazing students and brilliant dedicated faculty members
cons: The administration is unorganized and makes the lives of students more stressful. Too many stupid forms/emails to deal with just to get anything done. The IT department is a mess and makes the use of essential software difficult.

pros: Nice environment, great kids, primarily a positive experience.
cons: Middle management issues, low pay, too many additional items required by university policy distracting from primary academic purpose.

pros: Great experience working with students and faculty. The atmosphere was great and the environment was conducive to learning and broadening understanding of people from multiple cultures and backgrounds.
cons: There are no cons for this position. It is a great experience and I would suggest the position for any graduate student.

review_title: MTSU is not a place for people wanting to grow their industry knowledge or even stay current.
job_title: Web and Database Specialist in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: It is very difficulty to be fired. You get a lot of days off.
cons: It is very difficult to be fired. Traffic/parking is a terrible experience. The organizational culture is demotivating. Most people tend to do as little as possible.

pros: This job was very easy. I was able to work whenever I chose. I managed computers in four dorms around campus for ResNet, based out of Womack. I was allowed to work 20 hours a week, and the pay was minimum wage. It was more than fair.
cons: Sometimes things went wrong with the computers that I didn't understand. I feel like I'm pretty well versed in computer problems, but students have unpredictable needs.

review_title: Very good employer with great benefits
pros: Benefits are great. State puts an extra 10% of your salary into retirement account. There's a sick bank that you donate 2 sick days a year to but is there for unlimited sick time if you need it.. Great health insurance.
cons: The pay is average. Raises are few and far between. But, Murfreesboro has a fairly inexpensive cost of living with great schools and not much commute.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: Helps to cover your cost of education
cons: essentially indentured servitude. The pay is not enough to live on, so you either have to grind yourself into the ground looking for adjunct work at Vol State or other community colleges or you have to live off student loans.

review_title: I was a Resident Assistant at Scarlett Commons at Middle Tennessee State University.
pros: It was a great way to get experience in interpersonal communication
cons: There are no challenges of working here other than the fact that it is known that at other universities you do get free housing, but at MTSU RA's only get half off.

pros: Frequent raises, my salary has increased 268% in 21 years. Seems to be among the highest in the state for faculty of my standing.
cons: Heavy teaching load (4-4), otherwise very few. Admirable faculty governance, good values, steady growth.

review_title: A good introductory law enforcement experience as a dispatcher
pros:
Work with your schedule
Easy to swap around
Laid back environment
Variety of incidents
Become familiar with law enforcement
Good work environment
Hours aren't bad
cons:
Pay is terrible
Takes forever to make changes (like pay)
Some occasional drama

job_title: Adjunct Professor & Reference Librarian in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: The people at MTSU are great!  The academic environment is very stimulating, and th diverse student body allow you to know students from all around the world.  There is always something happening on campus, and everyone is encouraged to participate.  Love my work!
cons: It is difficult to obtain full time employment.

pros: I was able to work in a student leadership position while I finished my degree. I experienced more career development and growth in my short time there than any other position I have ever held.
cons: Pay is not great, but for student employment it is to be expected. The pros far outweigh this.

pros: Good benefits. Family/work life balance is ok. Some nice people that work there. Great opportunity to see great speakers on campus for free.
cons: No room for advancement. The facility is ran based on politics... Never received a raise in 5 years of working there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Middle City, TN
pros: I work as a GTA in the Chemistry department. The labs are pretty easy to teach because all the chemicals are already prepped for you the lab manager. The grading is easy too...Except for the organic labs. Just an okay place to work.
cons: The stipend is really low. Very very low.

review_title: Great place to work and learn
pros:
This university provides great learning environment.
It also has best infrastructure for research.
It is recognized as one of the best schools for aviation in the united States.
cons: -sometimes there can be funding constraints. Apart from  that, I cannot think of  any cons.

pros: Great students, colleagues, and support staff.
cons: Antiquated professorial model; lack of communication at all levels; lack of professional loyalty to contingent faculty.

pros: Colleagues were generally kind and easy to work with.
cons: Management was difficult and refused to communicate openly. No one understood what "success" looked like and how to achieve goals. Departments are siloed and there is no accountability for lack of effort. Leadership did not treat employees with respect.

pros: Competent, scholarly professionals leading ENGL and composition who will see, support, and inspire your commitment to effective, evidence-based teaching
cons: None -- I found support for teaching in all ares -- admin, it, faculty

review_title: Please improve the administration and resources
pros: Passionate and devoted people: the academia contains some very talented educators.
cons: Very few innovators, old facilities. Most departments have stayed the same for years.

pros: Nice people. I was little scared at first since it is such a big place.
cons: Too big. There are some good, some bad people.

job_title: Student Worker Farm Hand in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: Work around your class schedule. Great opportunity for learning relevant information about field of agriculture.  Very fulfilling work, learned  a lot from experienced workers. Great coworkers.
cons: Pay was not too great.

review_title: Flexibility for Student Workers at MTSU
pros: Every supervisor I had while an undergraduate student worker at MTSU was very understanding of the occasional sudden changes of schedule that came with being an involved student.
cons: There were very few downsides if any.

pros: Flexibility, low pressure, and nice place to work.
cons: Low pay, has to learn how to satisfy both low and high quality students.

review_title: It is ok, but theres a lot of room for improvement.
pros: Lots of overtime to compensate for the small pay
cons: No room for career development

pros: Lots of networking and connections; great growing town
cons:
Paid once a month 
Required to not leave the premises when on duty
Required a lot of unnecessary time

pros:
The university bends over backwards to have tutoring available for students.
Hours were fair especially if working while also taking classes.
cons: As a part time employee hours are limited to 29 hours per week.

pros: Great enviroment.Good staff thats professional.
cons: Monthly pay and personal training marketing isn't the best and there is too many trainers so hours are limited.

pros: Relaxed working environment, casual dress code, generous PTO and sick time.
cons: Limited ability for promotions. No formal career track or planning. Pay scale is below industry averages.

pros: Can do homework at the desk, learn how to deal with conflict, help build a community
cons: Pay is low, no technology at the desk, sometimes crazy hours

pros: Very kind staff, professional atmosphere, excellent time off and working your schedule around your life, great benefits
cons: More accommodating to student workers than to full-time staff

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Murfreesboro, TN
pros: The students are great and the faculty are supportive.
cons: The salary could be better but it is sufficient for basic living expense

review_title: Great benefits. Compensation is below other public organizations.
pros: Enjoy my work. Some great people.
cons: Compensation is horrible. Even community colleges in the area make better salaries than MTSU does.

review_title: Amazing time teaching my own class as a Graduate Student in the CSCI department.
pros: Amazing faculty.  Wonderful department.  Great experience.
cons: College students of this generation...

review_title: Great place to be part of..
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Murfreesboro, TN

cons: None that I can think of other than parking space issues.

pros: Assisting Associate and Assistant Professors who are active educators in my field
cons: Wish I could've spent more time learning from the professors

review_title: Experience as a Building Attendant at MTSU
pros: During downtime you can complete homework or study.
cons: Sometimes you are required to stay after your designated work hours.

pros:
Incredible schedule - set your own hours.
Tons of access to faculty willing to help you with anything.
cons: Monthly paycheck vs. bi-weekly paycheck.

pros: wonderful location, friendly people, great resources on campus
cons: high cost of living area because it is so close to Nashville

pros: Challenges to facilitate learning occur everyday
cons: I have experienced no cons

pros: Friendly , As a student its best place to work compared to food departments
cons: No real industry experience. Working with students

pros: Flexible work schedule, an engaging work environment, clean office space

review_title: A great university to work for!

pros: Endless amounts of students, so there is no shortage of work.
cons: Pay is lower than industry standard.

pros: Able to work and do your homework at the desk, and make connections!
